 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.

violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.

achieved.

If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact

your contract.

questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (616)552-3662.

ALLEGATION:
On 2/28/21, adult at the facility grabbed youth and pushed youth into the wall when
youth was trying to run down the hall. Youth has a few carpet burns from the fall on
forearms and knees.
INVESTIGATION:
On 3/1/2021 I received the allegation that Youth A was grabbed and pushed to a
wall by Staff 1 as Youth A was running down the hall. Youth A had carpet burns on
his forearms and knees. Additionally, the allegation indicated that the Complainant
had reviewed video footage of the incident and it appeared that Staff 1 did not push
Youth A, rather Youth A was “unintentionally tripped.”
INTERVIEWS
DHHS Worker 1 and I made an unannounced visit to the facility at 12:00PM on
3/1/21. We met with the Director of Quality and Risk with whom we reviewed the
video footage of the event and discussed a safety plan requiring Staff 1 to not have
contact with Youth A until the resolution of the investigation.
Youth A - DHHS Worker 1 and I interviewed Youth A in person. Youth A reported
that he and Youth B do not get along and they had gotten into an argument on
2/27/21 that resulted in Youth A being physically restrained. Youth A reported that
the following day, 2/28/21, Youth A was hitting, punching, and choking Staff 1. He
stated that he attempted to run down the hallway where Youth B’s room is located.
Youth A stated that Youth B had said he wanted to talk to Staff 1 earlier, so Youth A
was running to his room to tell him that Staff 1 couldn’t talk to him because he was
busy with Youth A. Youth A stated that he did not tell Staff 1 his intention when he
started to run but reported that he is not supposed to go down Youth B’s hallway and
will typically do so to make staff mad. Youth A reported that, as he was running
down the hall, Staff 1 ran after him and attempted to get in front of him. Youth A
reported that, as he was running, he tripped causing his knee to hit against a wall.
He stated that, at the time, he thought Staff 1 tripped him on purpose, but he thought
about it and realized that his foot hit a chair which caused him to trip and fall. He
stated that Staff 1 never physically came in contact with him as they were running
and denied having any injuries as a result of the fall. He reported that he feels safe
at the facility and has no concerns with staff.
3

On 3/2/21 DHHS Worker 1 and I made a scheduled visit to the facility at 1:30pm to
interview Staff 1 and Staff 2. Director of Quality and Risk was present during the
interviews.
Staff 1 - Staff 1 reported that on 2/8/21. Youth A had been escalated for
approximately an hour during which he was hitting, kicking, and choking Staff 1. He
stated that Youth A was not responding to de-escalation attempts and Staff 1 was
trying to keep Youth A’s focus on him so he wouldn’t direct his aggression toward
other staff or youth in the home. Youth A attempted to run down Youth B’s hallway
and since he had an altercation with Youth B earlier in the day, Staff 1 reported
feeling that he had to prevent Youth A from getting to Youth B’s room in order to
keep Youth B safe. Staff 1 stated that he perceives himself as a quick person, so he
thought he could run faster than Youth A and “body block” Youth A from getting to
Youth B’s room. When asked to describe a body block, Staff 1 stated that staff
members place their bodies in a position to prevent a youth from getting to a
destination. He stated that there is no specific proximity in which the staff place their
bodies. He stated that Youth A was faster than he expected, and he ended up
colliding with Youth A rather than getting in front of him and Youth A’s body hit
against a wall in the hallway. He stated that the collision was unintentional, but
Youth A immediately accused Staff 1 of hurting him intentionally. Staff 1 stated that
he apologized to Youth A, but he remained escalated and continued to be physically
aggressive with Staff 1. Staff 1 stated that he later learned that Staff 2 was already
down the hallway near Youth B’s bedroom and he should have allowed her to
prevent Youth A from getting to the room instead of running after Youth A. He stated
that he felt he had to protect Youth B and did what he thought was best in the
moment. Staff 1 stated that he didn’t feel that he could keep youth at the facility safe
anymore and would be resigning from his position.
Staff 2 - Staff 2 reported that on 2/28/21 Youth A had been chasing Youth B, so
Youth B went into his room. Staff 2 was in Youth B’s room with him, with her back
against the door to make sure Youth A couldn’t get inside because Youth A was
escalated and had a previous altercation with Youth B. She reported that when she
felt it was safe for her to leave the room because she couldn’t hear Youth A nearby,
she exited the room and stood in the hallway near the door. Youth A attempted to
run down the hall toward Youth B’s room and Staff 1 ran after him and tried to get in
front of him, but when they came around the corner, which is narrow, Staff 1
unintentionally collided with Youth A. She stated that she has worked with Staff 1 for
3 months and does not believe that he would intentionally trip or push a youth.
Director of Quality and Risk - Director of Quality and Risk reported that she has
addressed the use of the term body block with the staff trainers as this is not a term
used by CPI when teaching physical interventions. She states that she recognizes
the concerns with the method being used by staff as it has led to other incidents of
concern in the program.
4

Supervisor 1 - On 3/9/21 I interviewed Supervisor 1 along with DHHS Worker 1 via
video conferencing. Director of Quality and Risk was present during the interview.
Supervisor 1 reported that he heard Staff 2 call for assistance over the walkie talkie,
so he responded. When he arrived at the home where Staff 2 was working, he met
Staff 1 and Youth A outside of the home. Youth A was escalated and pushing Staff
1. Youth A told Supervisor 1 that Staff 1 had pushed him into a door. Supervisor 1
reported that Staff 1 interrupted and stated that’s not what happened. Youth A then
showed Supervisor 1 his right forearm and left leg. Supervisor 1 stated that the skin
in these areas looked irritated and was red and peeling. He reported that he watched
the video footage of the incident that night and it appeared to him that the collision in
the hallway was accidental.
VIDEO REVIEW
Youth A is seen hitting, kicking, and grabbing Staff 1’s face and neck while yelling at
Staff 1 after which Youth A takes off running toward hallway. Staff 1 runs after Youth
A and they collide at the entrance of the hallway, near a corner. Staff 1’s body
collides with Youth A’s right side, causing Youth A to fall sideways against a door
before falling to the floor. He immediately stands up and begins yelling at Staff 1 for
hurting him intentionally. Staff 2 is standing nearby in the hallway, in clear view of
the interaction.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
On 3/1/21 I received and reviewed a Critical Incident Report (CIR) completed by
Staff 1 on 2/28/21. The CIR documented the events as reported by Staff 1 during his
interview. No injuries were documented on the CIR.
On 3/1/21 I reviewed the training documents of Staff 1 verifying that he participated
in 2-hour verbal de-escalation training on 9/16/20, 14-hour CPI Initial Training
completed on 2/6/20, and a 3-hour CPI 90-day refresher on 6/8/20.
On 3/5/2021 I received and reviewed a Medical Note written by the facility’s Medical
Services Coordinator on 3/1/2021. The note documented that Youth A had a “red
area” on his left wrist that was “smaller than a dime but larger than a pen hole.” The
skin was not broken so no treatment was needed.
On 3/17/2021 I reviewed a copy of the behavior management system utilized by the
facility.
On 3/19/2021 I participated in a phone conference with DHHS Worker 1 during
which he reported that his investigation resulted in no findings.
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
qualifications.
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
ANALYSIS: During the course of his interview, Staff 1 stated that he did not
feel that he could keep youth at the facility safe.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4157 Behavior management.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that describe the
institution’s behavior management system. The
policies and procedures shall be reviewed annually
and updated as needed. These shall be available to
all residents, their families, and referring agencies.
ANALYSIS: Staff 1 violated the approved behavior management system
when he ran after Youth A, colliding with him and causing him to
fall and sustain rug burns.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The Critical Incident Report completed by Staff 1 did not include information about
the injuries sustained by Youth A.
INVESTIGATION:
Supervisor 1 - On 3/9/21 I interviewed Supervisor 1 along with DHHS Worker 1 via
video conferencing. Director of Quality and Risk was present during the interview.
Supervisor 1 reported that, on 2/28/21 Youth A showed Supervisor 1 his right
forearm and left leg after accusing Staff 1 of intentionally pushing him. Supervisor 1
stated that the skin in these areas looked irritated and was red and peeling. He
stated that Staff 1 was present when Youth A showed him the injuries and he
assumed Staff 1 would include that information when he completed a Critical
Incident Report, as required, which would in turn alert nursing staff to assess the
injury.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
On 3/1/21 I received and reviewed a Critical Incident Report (CIR) completed by
Staff 1 on 2/28/21. The CIR documented the events as reported by Staff 1 during his
interview. No injuries were documented on the CIR.
On 3/5/2021 I received and reviewed a Medical Note written by the facility’s Medical
Services Coordinator on 3/1/2021. The note documented that Youth A had a “red
area” on his left wrist that was “smaller than a dime but larger than a pen hole.” The
skin was not broken so no treatment was needed.
On 3/19/2021 I received and reviewed the facility’s Critical Incident and Adverse
Event Reporting Procedures.
7

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: Staff 1 did document the injuries sustained by Youth A in the
Critical Incident report he completed despite the form having a
section in which to do so.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

8

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4151 Emergency; continuity of operation procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written
emergency procedures that have been approved by the
department that maintain the continuity of operations for a
minimum of 72 hours to assure the safety of residents for
the following circumstances:
(a) Fire.
(b) Severe weather.
(c) Medical emergencies.
(d) Missing persons.
(f) Disasters.
(g) Utility failures.
ANALYSIS: Staff 1 was observed on video footage removing the required
Personal Protection Equipment.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
